properties.Comment: 'Old Blue' was a double-decker bus that was used for guided tours of campus and taking Alumni to football home games. The Alumni Association bought the bus in 1974. This photo was taken on Patterson Drive, Buell Armory and Peterson Service Building can be seen in the background.

This photo was taken at the campus botanical gardens, which is  directly adjacent to Barker Hall and Buell Armory. The Barker Hall and Buell Armory building was originally known as Alumni Hall and opened in 1901. The building consisted of a gym and a drill hall; it was used for physical education, clubs, dances, ROTC, and hosted the first UK basketball games - before moving to Alumni Gym in 1924. Barker Hall is named after Henry Stites Barker (university's second president); Buell Armory is named after Don Carlos Buell (trustee).

In the 1920s-1930s, the University purchased small farms south of the original campus to expand the agricultural campus. Urban development began rapidly on south campus after the opening of Chandler Medical Center in the 1960s. Today, UK Medical Center is Kentucky's flagship medical school for education, patient care, and research.

The Chemistry-Physics building was built in 1962. It was known as the most advanced science building in Kentucky when it opened. The building is currently undergoing major renovations to improve the infrastructure supporting the building and create laboratories to support modern scientific study. The renovation is scheduled for completion Summer of 2022.

Annual competitions between freshman and sophomore classes were common in the 1900's. UK held an annual flag rush, which ultimately ended in fights and injuries. President Barker (Second President) called for the competition to be put to an end in 1911. He was successful in ending flag rush, but he was made aware of students desire to continue class competitions and in 1913 instituted tug of war. A cable was stretched across Clifton Pond and the classes gathered on opposite sides, the winning team would pull the losing team into the pond. Today the area is known as the W.T. Young Library Rose Bowl, often students can be seen relaxing on the lawn on sunny days and sledding in snowy weather.

After UK separated from the private Kentucky University (Transylvania University today) to become a public institution, there was a state-wide bidding war for the university. To encourage UK to stay in Lexington, Fayette County offered $20,000 and the city offered $30,000 and a large fairground (original campus) at Maxwell Springs. The university's permanent location was declared Lexington in 1880, and construction of the original campus began. With the ample water supply from Maxwell Springs, an artificial lake was constructed north of the Main Building. The lake was drained by 1918, making way for the development of Alumni Gym (1924) and Student Union Building (1938). In 2018 the current Bill Gatton Student Center opened at this location.

In 1953 the College of Agriculture's dairy barn suffered a large fire damaging the upper portion of the barn. Because the structure itself was made out of concrete, it was determined that the building would be too costly to demolish. The dairy barn structure was repurposed and the interior was renovated into meeting spaces and landscape architecture studios. In 1974 the building was renamed after E.S. Good, head of Animal Husbandry and Animal Industries in the early to mid 1900's.

Kinkead Hall opened in 1930 as a new men's dormitory. The building was named after William B. Kinkead, a judge and University trustee. Today the Chemistry-Physics building sits directly across from Kinkead Hall, but previously that space was used for recreation and included tennis courts.

After receiving land from Lexington in 1880, the University saw the construction of the first three buildings: Main Building, White Hall Dormitory, and the president's house. The Main Building was originally used for classrooms, offices, and chapel. In 1948 the building's name was changed to Administration Building and was only used by administrative departments. The building had to undergo major renovations after a fire in 2001. The building is now used by administrative offices, the president's office, classrooms, and conference rooms. The Main Building is one of the three original buildings that made up the campus and is the only one still standing. The photo above is showing (left to right): White Hall Dormitory, Main Building, Neville Hall, and Ezra Gillis Building.

The section of road pictured was renamed Avenue of Champions after the 1950-1951 athletic season. Memorial Coliseum is on the left, and Stoll Field/McClean Stadium is on the right. In 1950 athletics was moved from Alumni Gym to Memorial Coliseum. In 1976 the men's basketball team moved to Rupp Arena in downtown Lexington, but Memorial Colesium is still home to women's basketball, volleyball, and gymnastics. Football was played at Stoll Field/McLean Stadium across the street from Memorial Coliseum. The concrete stands opened in 1916 as Stoll Field and in 1924 the stadium was renamed McLean Stadium after Price Innis McLean - a student-athlete that died as a result of injuries from a football game. In 1973, football moved to the newly constructed Commonwealth Stadium (Kroger Field) and the old stadium was demolished.

The University started its own radio broadcast called WBKY at McVey Hall in 1944. McVey Hall was named after Frank L. McVey (Third President). The station changed to WUKY in 1989 to better show affiliation with UK. WBKY-WUKY is known as the oldest university-operated FM station in the country and was the first public radio station in Kentucky. Today WUKY is located off the main campus in northwestern Lexington off Spurr Road. In this photo directly next to McVey Hall is the original observatory, with the campus's continued expansion the observatory moved to the corner of Woodland and Hilltop Ave in 1931. This was deemed a better place to have plenty of views and less light pollution. The observatory was eventually demolished in 1965.  A new observatory called MacAdam Student Observatory opened in 2008 and is still on campus today on the top of the Rose Street Garage.

Memorial Hall opened in 1929 as a memorial to soldiers from Kentucky who died in WWI.  The building has an auditorium, an outdoor amphitheater, an organ, classrooms, and dressing rooms. Inside the lobby, there are decorative panels listing by country the names of students who served in WWI and WWII. The building's clock tower has become an iconic symbol for the University.

The first library opened on campus in 1909. A total of $26,500 was donated by the Carnegie Foundation for construction. The library was called Carnegie Library (left) and it was one of two Carnegie Libraries in Lexington. Margaret I. King was the first librarian, and the second library on campus was dedicated to her in 1948. Carnegie Library was demolished in the 1960s to make way for the construction of Patterson Office Tower and White Hall Classroom Building. Miller Hall (right) was built in 1898 and was originally called Science Hall housing natural sciences. It was one of the first dedicated classroom buildings on campus. In 1940 the building was renamed Miller Hall after the first Dean of Arts and Sciences and professor of geology and zoology, Arthur McQuiston Miller. Today Miller Hall is used for administrative purposes and student success.

Neville Hall was built in 1890 and was the fifth building constructed on campus. The building opened as a new dormitory but was remodeled for classrooms in 1918. Neville Hall was named after John H. Neville a Latin and Greek professor and Vice President. The building was occupied by the departments of Hygiene, Psychology, and Dispensary.  Despite being recommended for abandonment in 1937, the building continued to be used until it caught fire in 1961. The severity of the damage called for the building to be demolished.
Prior to vending machines, a variety of food carts were on campus for students to buy snacks from. Pictured here is a fruit cart vendor outside of Neville Hall.

In the 1960's President Patterson's House, the original White Hall Dormitory, and Carnegie Library were tore down to build White Hall Classroom Building and Patterson Office Tower (POT). The construction of these two buildings completely changed the landscape of central campus from original historic constructions. White Hall Classroom Building is largely used for classroom and lab space. Patterson Office Tower is an 18 floor bluilding primarily used for faculty office space and conference rooms. It is currently the tallest building on campus since the demolition of the Kirwan-Blanding Towers in 2020.

The Lexington and Ohio Railroad was the first railroad chartered in Kentucky. Completed in 1834 the railroad connected Lexington and Frankfort; later in 1851 connection to Louisville was added. The 'Original Rails and Stones' Lexington and Ohio Railroad monument was located on the University's campus. The monument consisted of a portion of restored original track and a bronze plaque set on a large concrete base. It was donated by H. Bennett Faris, a retired railroad man, and University trustee. The monument can be seen in the foreground of this photo, with a portion of Memorial Hall (left) and Mathews Building (right) in the background. The monument was removed in 2014 for the construction of the Carol Martin Gatton Business and Economics Building.

As the agricultural program grew and campus continued expanding, the Experiment Station needed to move closer to the farms and have a larger space than Gillis Building. Scovell Hall opened in 1905 as the new Agricultural Experiment Station Building, and continued to be a center for agricultural research until the 1990's. Scovell Hall was named after Melville Amasa Scovell, the first director of the Experiment Station and director/dean of the College of Agriculture. He greatly grew the agricultural program during his tenure (1885-1912); staff increased from 3 to 60, departments from 2 to 11, and the farm expanded from 48.5 to 240 acres.

Stoll Field is known as the home of the first-ever collegiate game played in the south in 1880. The game was between Kentucky University (Transylvania University) and Centre College, the field was not used by UK until 1881. The field later became the center of sporting events; used for football, baseball, and other intramural sports. The formal stadium opened in 1916 and was dedicated as Stoll Field in honor of Judge Richard G. Stoll (Student-Athlete and Board of Trustee member). In 1924 the stadium was renamed McLean Stadium after a student-athlete (Price Innis McLean) died from injuries sustained in a football game. After Commonwealth Stadium (Kroger Field) opened in 1973, Stoll Field/McLean Stadium was demolished.

The Cooper House was built around 1865 but was not acquired by the University until 1887 to be a residence for the Experiment Station director/dean. Thomas Poe Cooper, who was dean of the College of Agriculture and Home Economics, and director of Experiment Station (agricultural dean), moved into the house in 1918. The house was located on the Agricultural Experiment Station and was surrounded by 48.5 acres of farmland for research. In 1969 the house stopped being used as a residence for the Experiment Station director/dean and became office space for the Landscape Architecture Department. The house is currently vacant as it is undergoing renovation/restoration. Directly adjacent to Cooper House the new home for the James B. Beam Institute for Kentucky Spirits and Maturation House are being built.

In 1923 it was determined that the old gym at Alumni Hall (Barker Hall/Buell Armory) was unsafe and not sufficient for attendance. The 2,800-seat Alumni Gym opened in 1924 in an area that had previously been a lake. This is where the legacy of Kentucky basketball began. Men's Basketball moved to Memorial Coliseum (8,500 capacity) in 1950, and later to Rupp Arena (20,500 capacity) in downtown Lexington in 1976. Today Alumni Gym has been renovated into a modern two-floor gym and has been integrated with the Bill Gatton Student Center.

The Margaret I King Library was named in honor of Margaret Isadora King, the University's first librarian. The M. I. King Library opened in 1931 to replace the first library on campus, Carnegie Library. The King Library North addition was completed in 1974. This library became the main library on campus until the opening of William T. Young Library in 1998. Today the M. I. King Library is used for Specials Collections, Map Collections, Science Library, the King Library Press, and other offices.

When President Patterson retired in 1910 he continued to live on campus in the Patterson House (original residence constructed for the president). Maxwell Place was built around 1870 and was purchased by the University in 1917 to be the official president's house. President Frank L. McVey was the first to move in. This photo is showing the construction in preparation for the McVeys to move in. It involved additions at the back of the residence and a long pergola leading to the main entrance.

Even though women were permitted to enroll at the university starting in 1880, it was not until 1904 that Patterson Hall opened as the first woman's dormitory. Women previously had to make other arrangements off-campus. The dorm is named after the University's first president (James K. Patterson). To avoid close interactions between women and men students, Patterson Hall was the first building constructed off the main campus. Patterson Hall is the oldest dorm still present on campus.

In 1973 UK Football moved from Stoll Field/McLean Stadium to the newly constructed Commonwealth Stadium increasing the attendance capacity from 37,000 to 57,800. The stadium is built on the south end of campus on what once was the Experiment Station Farm. This historic photo is showing an opening event dinner that was held outside the stadium. The stadium has undergone several renovations since its opening, including various expansions and audio-visual upgrades. Today the stadium holds approximately 61,000 people and was renamed Kroger Field in 2017. The field itself is named C. M. Newton Grounds, after the former UK athletic director.

In 1889 Ezra Gillis Building was built as UK's first Agricultural Experiment Station. In 1891 the building was destroyed by fire and rebuilt at the same location. The building was named after Ezra Gillis (first registrar) in 1978, prior to that the building was known as the Chemistry Building and Administration Annex. As one of the oldest structures still standing on campus, the building has been used for many different educational disciplines and purposes including Chemistry, Law, Health Services, Admissions, Registrar, and today the Graduate School. As campus began obtaining more land south of campus a new Experiment Station was built on the edge of campus.

Mathews Building opened in 1907 as a new Agriculture Building, shortly after Scovell Hall. The building was named after Clarence Wentworth Mathews the dean of the College of Agriculture from 1908-1910. He had a home and garden built between Mathews Building and Scovell Hall. His home and garden were donated to the University in 1968, and are known as Mathews House and Mathews Garden today.

The first College of Education Building was completed in 1930, the building was later named after the first dean William S. Taylor in 1949. The building housed the College of Education and the University School which offered classes to children from Kindergarten through High School as a training opportunity for student teachers. In 1962, because of a high increase in teaching students, the University School closed and the College of Education began making partnerships with local schools to offer plenty of opportunities for student teachers to get field experience.
James K. Patterson was president of university from 1878-1910. This is a photo from the 1910 commencement ceremony. The event was held on the front lawn of the Main Building.

The university saw large growth in the 1940s because veterans were returning home from WWII and enrolling in college. This created more of a demand for classrooms and residence halls, especially residences for families. To meet the housing need Herman Lee Donovan (4th President) called for the development of Cooperstown to be set up with temporary homes. Cooperstown is named after Thomas Poe Cooper, who was dean of the College of Agriculture and Home Economics, and director of Experiment Station. Cooperstown was initially set up with 334 prefabricated war surplus buildings. Rent was 35 dollars a month to stay in one of these prefabricated homes. In 1956 seven permanent apartment buildings were built to replace the temporary homes. It provided 330 one and two bedroom apartments, the rental rate started at75 dollars a month. The Cooperstown Apartments were demolished in 2012 for the development of the new Woodland Glen Complex that stands in its location today.

Under the Morill Land-Grant Act, which allowed the University to become its own public institution, military training was a requirement for all students. During the 1880s men were required to wear military-style uniforms and participate in drills for the cadet corps in front of the Main Building. The initial training was not designed to develop officers. The United States noticed a need for a large number of trained officers during World War I and in 1916 established the Reserve Officers' Training Corp (ROTC) to provide college-educated officers that could be called to active duty during times of war. UK established its ROTC program in 1917 and continues today.
